messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Incidentally, I just learned that, by default, an exception /is/ its own
> cause in JDK 1.4, so are you sure you want to stop people from doing that?

That's not quite what's going on. getCause() "Returns the cause of this
throwable or null if the cause is nonexistent or unknown. (The cause is
the throwable that caused this throwable to get thrown.)" Further
initCause is specified to throw an IllegalArgumentException "if cause is
this throwable. (A throwable cannot be its own cause.)" The getCause
method works like this:

public Throwable getCause() {
return (cause==this ? null : cause);
}

The intiCause method looks like this:

public synchronized Throwable initCause(Throwable cause) {
if (this.cause != this)
throw new IllegalStateException("Can't overwrite cause");
if (cause == this)
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Self-causation not
permitted");
this.cause = cause;
return this;
}

I don't know why internally the default cause is set to this. I suspect
it's some sort of optimization, but this is purely a private
implementation detail. It is never exposed through the public API.

> This I understand. I guess I've just never seen that level of
> sophistication in exception classes before. It looks like unnecessary
> complexity to me, but then I don't understand the problems you're trying
> to solve. I'm sure that if you explained it to me over beer, I would see
> it differently. :)

It's implementation complexity, but it results in less API complexity.
Better to reuse the existing, standard API than to invent something new.
If you want chained exception handling that's compatible across
versions, this is what you need.
